comment.body:
> Not sure why it didn't get updated in previous pulls from upstream, though.

Don't understand this either. Nor why I didn't catch/check the effect of #1478 to documentation then :-( But then it's now "fixed".

pull_request.title: Pull Neon implementation of Falcon from PQClean
pull_request.body:
<!-- Please give a brief explanation of the purpose of this pull request. -->

Pull the ARM Neon implementation of Falcon from PQClean on behalf of @cothan. See https://github.com/PQClean/PQClean/pull/493, https://github.com/PQClean/PQClean/pull/497

<!-- Does this PR resolve any issue?  If so, please reference it using automatic-closing keywords like "Fixes #123." -->

<!-- Please answer the following questions to help manage version and changes across projects. -->

* [ ] Does this PR change the input/output behaviour of a cryptographic algorithm (i.e., does it change known answer test values)?  (If so, a version bump will be required from *x.y.z* to *x.(y+1).0*.)
* [ ] Does this PR change the list of algorithms available -- either adding, removing, or renaming? Does this PR otherwise change an API? (If so, PRs in [oqs-provider](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/oqs-provider), [OQS-OpenSSL](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/openssl), [OQS-BoringSSL](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/boringssl), and [OQS-OpenSSH](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/openssh) will also need to be ready for review and merge by the time this is merged.)

<!-- Once your pull request is ready for review and passing continuous integration tests, please convert from a draft PR to a normal PR, and request a review from one of the OQS core team members. -->

repo.name: liboqs
repo.description: C library for prototyping and experimenting with quantum-resistant cryptography

repo.name: liboqs
repo.description: C library for prototyping and experimenting with quantum-resistant cryptography

comment.body: Can we get this from the package version instead? The fewer places I need to update things...

pull_request.title: Allow finding and linking system deps
pull_request.body:
Addresses #190 

Adds necessary changes to optionally detect the system liboqs version and link to it.

To consider:

- Should there be a `vendor` feature, or can we defer to `pkg-config` crate's env var configuration (e.g. "LIBOQS_NO_PKG_CONFIG")
- Is targeting the minor version (>= `0.8.0` && < `0.9.0`) enough?

Tested this manually with a system-installed build of liboqs 0.8.0-rc1. Not sure how best to test this in CI yet.

comment.body: rather than letting this depend on successfully finding the system library, I think I would rather use a `vendored` feature like `openssl-sys`.

pull_request.title: Allow finding and linking system deps
pull_request.body:
Addresses #190 

Adds necessary changes to optionally detect the system liboqs version and link to it.

To consider:

- Should there be a `vendor` feature, or can we defer to `pkg-config` crate's env var configuration (e.g. "LIBOQS_NO_PKG_CONFIG")
- Is targeting the minor version (>= `0.8.0` && < `0.9.0`) enough?

Tested this manually with a system-installed build of liboqs 0.8.0-rc1. Not sure how best to test this in CI yet.

comment.body: I think we could get the lower range bound from the crate version, but not sure how to handle upper bounds. With system packages that we don't have control over, it seems we should be flexible at least until the next incompatible version.

pull_request.title: Allow finding and linking system deps
pull_request.body:
Addresses #190 

Adds necessary changes to optionally detect the system liboqs version and link to it.

To consider:

- Should there be a `vendor` feature, or can we defer to `pkg-config` crate's env var configuration (e.g. "LIBOQS_NO_PKG_CONFIG")
- Is targeting the minor version (>= `0.8.0` && < `0.9.0`) enough?

Tested this manually with a system-installed build of liboqs 0.8.0-rc1. Not sure how best to test this in CI yet.

comment.body: Per semver, the next incompatible version from `0.8.x` is `0.9.0`. We should be able to simply decide this through "current minor version + 1"

pull_request.title: Allow finding and linking system deps
pull_request.body:
Addresses #190 

Adds necessary changes to optionally detect the system liboqs version and link to it.

To consider:

- Should there be a `vendor` feature, or can we defer to `pkg-config` crate's env var configuration (e.g. "LIBOQS_NO_PKG_CONFIG")
- Is targeting the minor version (>= `0.8.0` && < `0.9.0`) enough?

Tested this manually with a system-installed build of liboqs 0.8.0-rc1. Not sure how best to test this in CI yet.

comment.body:
I'll add a `vendored` feature to both crates. My idea is, if `vendored` is enabled, the crate forces vendored sources, otherwise it checks for system library but still allows fallback to the vendor.

Note that the user can also force vendor via the `LIBOQS_NO_PKG_CONFIG` env var as specified in the pkg_config crate

comment.body: The problem is, we'd have to parse the version string if I understand correctly, and I don't know if we should do that manually, add some semver crate or sth else.

comment.body:
Seems we can just use these environment variables:

```
CARGO_PKG_VERSION_MAJOR  The major version of your package.
CARGO_PKG_VERSION_MINOR  The minor version of your package.
CARGO_PKG_VERSION_PATCH  The patch version of your package.
```

comment.body:
This might be any value in `0.8.100..0.8.199`, to refer to the versions of this wrapper that packages lib's `0.8.1` per our versioning scheme in the README. 

So we need this lower bound to be restricted a bit less by taking only the first character of the patch version.

comment.body:
I don't know how possible it is that liboqs reaches version e.g. 0.8.10, but I'd probably apply logic like:

if patch version is at least 3 chars long, cut out the last two
